objdescid.compdate: c. 1789The date is based on the relationship between this preliminary drawing and *The Book of Thel*, dated 1789 on its title page.

objinfo.medium: pencilThe British Museum accession number is stamped in ink lower left.
objinfo.watermark: top portion only of a fleur-de-lis watermark

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; the dealer Bernard Quaritch, offered in his Nov. 1882 catalogue, item 346 with 39 other works (£36), catalogue 350 of 10 Aug. 1883, item 13843, same group and price, *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts* of Oct. 1883, item 13843, same group and price, and catalogue of *William Blake's Original Drawings* of May 1885, no item number, same group and price; sold by Quaritch on 30 June 1886 to W. Graham Robertson; sold from Robertson's collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 63 with four other works by Blake (£42 to the dealer Maggs Bros. Ltd.); offered by Maggs, 1949 catalogue 117 of Sept. 1949, item 498 (£35); the dealer Ernest Seligmann; sold 1960 to W. A. Caro; his daughter, Ann Caro, probably by gift or inheritance; sold by Ann Caro to the British Museum in late 1982 for approximately £3000 and accessioned by the Museum in 1983.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Prints and Drawings: prints@britishmuseum.org

desc.objtitle: Sketch for "The Book of Thel," Plate 6, object 1 (Butlin 218 verso)

objnote.p: This sketch is a preliminary for the headpiece on plate 6 of Blake's *The Book of Thel*. See also the sketches on the recto of this leaf for two plates in the book, *Sketches for "The Book of Thel": Thel and the Clod of Clay, and Thel Fleeing From the House of Clay*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This sketch is a preliminary for the headpiece on plate 6 of Blake's *The Book of Thel*. Just left of the center of the composition, Thel, a standing female figure seen from the back, wears a gown and raises both arms with bent elbows. She faces up and to the right in the direction of a male figure, the personified "Cloud" of the poem, with long hair who flies or hovers in a horizontal position. His right arm is extended, finger pointed, and left leg bent downward. A cloud may support this figure or, alternatively, drapery from his clothing may surround him. There may be an object near the bottom left corner of the composition (perhaps vegetation?) as well as an object (a cloud outline?) to the left of the standing figure's head.

component.illusobjdesc: Just left of the center of the composition, Thel, a gowned female figure seen from the back, stands or walks away from the viewer and raises both arms with bent elbows. Her hair is short. She faces up and to the right in the direction of a male figure, the personified Cloud, who flies or hovers in a horizontal position. Thel's left leg and foot (which may be clad in a shoe) are extended slightly backward.

A male figure with long hair, the personified Cloud of *The Book of Thel*, flies or hovers in a horizontal position in the upper right quadrant of the composition. His right arm is extended, finger pointed, and left leg bent downward behind an extended right leg. His body faces forward, but he turns his head down and to the left, likely to look at the standing figure below. He may be nude or lightly draped in some sort of flowing gown. A cloud may support this figure or, alternatively, drapery may surround him.
The male figure upper right, the personified Cloud, may be supported by a cloud or, alternatively, drapery may surround her.

A few lines lower left may be a place-holder for the vegetation and the personified Worm pictured in *The Book of Thel* plate 6, for which this sketch is a preliminary drawing. Similarly, the line or lines left of the standing figure's head may be a cloud outline.
